document.title: Illinois Culturally Responsive Teaching and Leading Standards

C3B260D7688E4F26BA38EA9639251D3E.description:
Ensure classroom and building decorations are inclusive of all students throughout
 the building or within the community or city at large.

9066BEB84D4045D98291450913AC3FAD.description:
Verify that course materials are representative of all students, including materials
 for centers, stations, labs, classroom libraries, etc.

39434BAF037340FF9EFB6D123050A5D7.description:
Ensure linguistic diversity is represented throughout the building and seek ways to
 reflect representation of world languages.

73B86BA94F8F47418B5F50C5263D0C4A.description:
Uphold systems of support that create, promote, and sustain a welcoming and
 inclusive community.

606E375414834B3980C869E5E42CD998.description:
Student Representation in the Learning Environment – Culturally responsive teachers and
 leaders ensure the diversity of their student population is equally represented within the
 learning environment. In turn, all members of the student population feel seen, heard, and
 affirmed. Exceptionally well-versed culturally responsive teachers and leaders provide
 exposure to underrepresented or misrepresented minority groups, even when they are not
 present within the population of their school and community at large. The culturally
 responsive teacher and leader will:

842623389A0D42DA91374869B7D3853C.description:
Consider a broader modality of student assessments, such as performance
 portfolios, essays, multiple choice, State exams, oral examination, community
 assessments, work experiences, social justice work, action research projects, and
 recognition beyond academia.

BE79208DD307466A99E8EDE8A125E6E6.description:
Promote robust discussion with the intent of raising consciousness that reflects
 modern society and the ways in which cultures and communities intersect.

D437AFFBAFEC49A48996C67454EABC22.description: Use a resource tool to assess the curriculum and assessments for biases.

40B5E655CD484A4DAF1F93C8A9248E55.description:
Ensure teacher and students co-create content that encourages critical thinking
 about culture and includes counternarratives to dominant culture.

92E0DDA51B2E446799586BEDE59E03D8.description: Ensure text selections reflect students' classroom, community, and family culture.

4A5AC9AA1775421C85B7EF033817B852.description:
Implement and integrate the wide spectrum and fluidity of identities in the
 curriculum.

08B337DFC8AE4015B6107C664D10301E.description:
Assess one's story through multiple vantage points to gain a whole narrative that
 includes all sides of parties involved.

15A83FD8DEBC4D3DA8D593246679E764.description:
Embrace and encourage a balance of viewpoints and perspectives that leverage asset
 thinking toward traditionally marginalized populations.

4F67E18B75B046F5A7BDDB8E003011EB.description:
Ensure assessments reflect the enriched curriculum that has embedded student
 identities.

C8961A7494D64D48BCF02B63F7AB3993.description:
Employ authentic and modern technology usage inspiring digital literacy
 through an equity lens.

65AD42604F5043DC98E91255FB6033FA.description:
Identify and articulate the purposeful ways in which marginalized communities
 are represented in curriculum, including print, digital media, and other
 classroom resources.

9A0D16B802CD4C09A79849A56B1FFC9C.description:
Content Selections in all Curricula – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders intentionally
 embrace student identities and prioritize representation in the curriculum. In turn, students
 are not only given a chance to identify with the curriculum, they become exposed to other
 cultures within their schools and both their local and global communities. The culturally
 responsive teacher and leader will:

8136C66A866642B3BE7E870952DF9C98.description:
Collaborate effectively over time with the local community and community
 agencies, when and where appropriate, to promote a positive environment for
 student learning.

FAB4CB732E4841FA8B779FD030CAFA33.description:
Communicate and provide appropriate techniques and materials to support and
 enrich student learning at home.

02377B6FCFE942718447C4329EB9E1E1.description: Welcome communication from parents and reply in a timely manner.

279421D4C21945E1B854EC62718C4719.description:
Invite family and community members to teach about topics that are culturally
 specific and aligned to the classroom curriculum or content area.

9F52E05113004C0C8E3ACE98078F743C.description:
Foster students' cultural understanding and connection to the surrounding
 community.

C4C3F4B667094036BA3BCAC1E2F4BB17.description:
Develop relationships with families and the community outside of the classroom
 setting.

E8ECBBCFF62D49B681861A15CF9CE286.description:
Use best practices that are culturally responsive to value students and their families'
 cultural traditions when recognizing, motivating, encouraging, and supporting
 student success and growth.

26DD178B9A2345F1A66C919B7B94AD7D.description:
Continuously learn and build cultural knowledge that families and the community
 bring to the school community to nurture and foster relationships and inform
 student learning experiences.

8030734D2032407F9B8ED05596E76D82.description:
Forge ongoing participation with families and community members to meet the
 diverse needs and interests of students.

7EFCB6489C58445A96A1B9C98C5CAF38.description:
Actively seek multiple perspectives and contribution from families and the
 community and invite them to actively share their opinions, feedback, and concerns
 that impact the school community.

4130DF34722F418B86B17F2CBBC4E515.description:
Regularly interact with students, families, and communities in both English and home
 language through methods of their preference.

EEA972B73B7F4CC0BC467308C809C2A8.description:
Family and Community Collaboration – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders will
 partner with families and communities to build rapport, form collaborative and mutual
 relationships, and engage in effective cross-cultural communication. The culturally responsive
 teacher and leader will:

C8B57D26091746D09082A40BDC04E99D.description:
Give students space to solve their own problems, negotiate their advocacy needs,
 and present their perspectives.

F11B7154A1F6495596B76F8166281F57.description:
Communicate high expectations to which all students can be held and urge students
 to lead as student advocates appropriate to the students' age and development.

2741496BA61C42F7BB13155A3171E9FC.description: Research and offer student advocacy content with real world implications.

89756FDFE96348ED81EE8B5435CA0EEA.description: Create a risk-taking space that promotes student advocacy.

35578B9DA4F44B33B0B76A6543390E0B.description:
Help students identity actions that can be taken to apply learning to develop
 opportunities and relationships for alliances.

A419BA3D95194628AE4E5A1C818AF164.description:
Include students in the creation of an inclusive learning community with more
 opportunities for student expression.

EC96EEF064DA4D9EB858586D44A23FD9.description: Offer guidance to students on how to develop a self-advocacy plan to inform decisions and choices.

8ECEC423C80440F79165A1ABE911A9D1.description: Emphasize and connect with students about their identities, advocacies, and self-        interest.

6C682265D42847E59784B9BF695A6162.description: Leveraging Student Advocacy – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders will support and create opportunities for student advocacy and representation in the content and classroom. The culturally responsive teacher and leader will:

9D93739E3FFF4E81A09A61C8C7385C29.description: Persistently solicit student feedback, value that feedback (resist defensiveness), and adjust based on that feedback.

DE1F9A47905B43B286BF0C38791C3CA9.description: Create and embed student leadership opportunities into the student experience (e.g., peer-led discussion, student-led workshops, and student- run schoolwide initiatives).

A158134D6A2A44818B50BCFFC44CB82F.description: Co-create, with students, the collective expectations and agreements regarding the physical space and social-emotional culture of the classroom and school.

2FAD525327124C9DA715748C50579F27.description: Consistently solicit students' input on the curriculum (e.g., interests, people, or concepts).

6CFD68D3CAC54343B6D5B56957F17457.description: Make authentic connections between academic learning and students' prior knowledge, native language, culture, and values.

577145027DFD4E6BBCB75B1EFB1A6B10.description: Encourage and affirm the personal experiences (family, community, culture, etc.) students share in the classroom.

078558C6A51844DAB38DB4F6E175419C.description: Students as Co-Creators – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders who fundamentally believe all students are capable center learning around students' experiences and position them as co-creators, with emphasis on prioritizing historically marginalized students. The culturally responsive teacher and leader will:

94ECA5688D004D80981813F84AB3CC35.description: Set holistic goals for students that accommodate multiple ways of demonstrating strengths and success, (e.g., alternate academic achievement metrics, growth indicators, leadership, character development, social- emotional learning competencies, and school values).

A9FE8BFF33404EDF933C49F355A8FDC4.description: Provide multiple opportunities for parents to communicate in their language and method of preference, to the greatest extent possible.

FA0D3665F62B4315B27B234B6B011D4A.description: Share the classroom systems and policies (expectations, agreements, recognition and incentive practices, etc.) used in the classroom with students' families and align them to the values and cultural norms of those families.

0CB985C732954A50B0DDDD261AF749A7.description:
Provide parents with information about what their child is expected to learn,
 know, and do at his or her grade level and ways to reinforce concepts at home.

F9CF4BD5D0C94F0B95FB357C72A24587.description: Develop positive, strength-based partnerships with students and their families by learning about them, soliciting their opinions, and valuing their expectations, especially with those marginalized by schools in the past.

0546E61990174834B8CF887B8B00AEE7.description: Engage with students’ families and community members outside of the classroom to develop a more holistic understanding of the students’ lived experiences.

6E86CD66358B4F448CF978810AB7E300.description: Learn from and about their students’ culture, language, and learning styles to make instruction more meaningful and relevant to their students’ lives.

AC702C07780B410FB6E639CF306B2251.description: Students as Individuals – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders view and value their  students as individuals within the context of their families and communities. The culturally  responsive teacher and leader will:

E7DC192BF1A843EF9296F2833E3F2B50.description: Understand how a system of inequity reinforces certain suppositions as the norm.

84E7C975415A43829F814A1A69771914.description: Understand how a system of inequity creates rules regarding student punishment that negatively impact students of color.

AEF7C0F790434F7B91190450DC9640D9.description: Be aware of the effects of power and privilege and the need for social advocacy and social action to better empower diverse students and communities.

FAEE90E019B14C529635254F8FF03283.description: Understand how current curriculum and approaches to teaching impact students who are not a part of the dominant culture.

04C69EBE002B4BE084388F5D6C5F54AC.description: Know and understand how the system of inequity has impacted them as an  educator.

BD997753DC8341C7B3A7DCE3E2415E77.description: Collaborate with colleagues to determine how students from different backgrounds experience the classroom, school, and district

7DA84DB5E1D14F8DB0182940E21ACF91.description:
Understand the difference between prejudice, discrimination, racism, and how to
 operate at the interpersonal, intergroup, and institutional levels.

7EAAA8F1414D4F9B8E358CEEB91CF401.description:
Systems of Oppression – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders understand that there
 are systems in our society especially, but not limited to, our school system, that create and
 reinforce inequities, thereby creating oppressive conditions. Educators work actively against
 these systems in their everyday roles in educational institutions. The culturally responsive
 teacher and leader will:

7B416C43F3524960865DAA411EA7417B.description:
Assess how their biases and perceptions affect their teaching practice and how they
 access tools to mitigate their own behavior (racism, sexism, homophobia, unearned
 privilege, Eurocentrism, etc.).

65F9D7E529E24D878354A2217A258E2B.description:
Critically think about the institutions in which they find themselves working to
 reform these institutions whenever and wherever necessary.

0C36100A49474C649D2A9A92AFA9D589.description: Educate themselves about students’ communities, cultures, and histories.

D16ED7A9493448688933EA433886BF34.description:
Recognize how their identity (race/ethnicity, national origin, language, sex and
 gender, gender identity, sexual orientation, physical/developmental/ emotional
 ability, socioeconomic class, religion, etc.) affects their perspectives and beliefs about
 pedagogy and students.

41FD10F4B2BD4110B6D8C0223496295E.description:
Explore their own intersecting identities, how they were developed, and how they
 impact daily experience of the world.

CC23E641EEA543358387E83B235724EC.description:
Engage in self-reflection about their own actions and interactions and what ideas and
 biases motivated those actions.

F1D5D1CD59364DA4A944C63B54479727.description:
Include representative, familiar content in the curriculum to legitimize students’
 backgrounds, while also exposing them to new ideas and worldviews different from
 their own.

49B498CE8E4A4572AD9C0ABDE620E6DB.description: Know about their students and their lives outside of school, using this knowledge to  build instruction that leverages prior knowledge and skills.

BBE2461C0699423696F25A5523917054.description:
Approach their work and students with an asset-based mindset, affirming the validity
 of the students’ backgrounds and identities.

1E82361B91C14AD686317FA0B45DBC29.description:
Understand and value the notion that multiple lived experiences exist, that there is
 often not one "correct" way of doing or understanding something, and that what is
 seen as "correct" is most often based on our lived experiences.

36A939D818A242D08CA71995926759FE.description:
Self-Awareness and Relationships to Others – Culturally responsive teachers and leaders are
 reflective and gain a deeper understanding of themselves and how they impact others,
 leading to more cohesive and productive student development as it relates to academic and
 social-emotional development for all students. The culturally responsive teacher and leader
 will:
